item.title: Fortnite: How to Find the Business Turret (& How It Works)
item.description:
In Fortnite Chapter 6 Season 2, the villain of the main storyline owns the maps on the island, so besides the gold hidden inside, gamers have an additional incentive to want to rob them. Unfortunately, the Bank Vaults in Fortnite are heavily guarded by the Baron's henchmen, and it can tough trying to open a vault door while getting attacked by several grunts at once.

Thankfully, the Business Turret is back in Fortnite , and it's a great item for players who want the extra protection in battle. This guide will show players how to find the Business Turret, how to use it, and how much damage it does.

How to Find the Business Turret in Fortnite

The Business Turret is an Epic rarity item, so it can be quite hard to find. Even though there is a chance gamers will stumble upon the Business Turret as regular floor loot, they'll have a better chance of finding it if they search chests.

To increase their chances of finding Business Turrets in Fortnite , players should focus on looting chest containers . Therefore, searching areas with tons of chests, such as large named locations and vaults, is the best way to go. Lastly, if players have gold to spare, they can get the Business Turret at a Black Market for 600 gold bars .

How the Business Turret Works in Fortnite

Tips on How to Use the Business Turret

Once the player has a Business Turret in their inventory, they can throw it like any other item, and it'll automatically start shooting enemy players and hostile NPCs. Therefore, setting up a Business Turret outside a vault door is a great way to avoid being overtaken by grunts and being caught off guard while looting .

The Business Turret deals seven damage for each shot that connects. It doesn't sound like much, but it has a high rate of fire, so it can become lethal within seconds.

  • The Business Turret has a range of 60 meters, so if players move farther away, it will lose connection and self-destruct within seven seconds . It will also self-destruct if the player sets up another Business Turret - gamers can only have one active turret at a time. When gamers are done using the Business Turret in a certain location, they can pick it back up and take it with them - it's a portable item.

To deal with an enemy Business Turret, players can shoot it to destroy it or eliminate its owner.

item.title: Diablo 4 Has the Chance to Repeat History Thanks to the Switch 2
item.description:
While Diablo 4 fans may be waiting some time for the game's next major expansion, which isn't planned for release until 2026, there may be other surprises in store for the game in the meantime. Blizzard recently released the 2025 roadmap for Diablo 4 , and while it didn't wow many fans, there were a few treats for players to look forward to. However, there is one unrevealed release that could be even more exciting than anything listed on this roadmap, and it would involve the upcoming Nintendo Switch 2.

Although nothing has been confirmed, a Diablo 4 Switch 2 release would be a great way to tap into a new audience for the ARPG. While the Diablo series hasn't always been associated with Nintendo, the Switch paved the way for this partnership to be so with releases like Diablo 3: Eternal Collection and Diablo 2: Resurrected on the platform. With major third-party titles like Elden Ring and Cyberpunk 2077 confirmed for Switch 2 ports, it seems like Diablo 4 would fit right at home on the console, and repeat a feat that Diablo 3 's Switch 1 release pulled off.

Diablo 4 Could Be to the Switch 2 What Diablo 3 Was to Its Predecessor

Diablo 3 on the Switch Was the Series' First Nintendo Console Appearance

Diablo is most often associated with PC gaming, with the first two games rising to acclaim on the platform before Diablo 3 made the jump to consoles on the Xbox 360 and PS3 in 2012. More recently, the series has found a new home on the Nintendo Switch with Diablo 3: Eternal Collection releasing on the console in 2018, and Diablo 2: Resurrected released for it later in 2021. Diablo 3 on the Switch marked an important point for Nintendo fans, as it was the first time a game in the franchise was playable on a Nintendo console.

Diablo 3: Eternal Collection included the base game plus the Reaper of Souls and Rise of the Necromancer expansions.

Diablo 3: Eternal Collection also came at the perfect time for the Switch, releasing just over a year after the console launched and bringing with it exclusive Zelda -themed content for Switch players, including Ganondorf transmog armor, Cucco pet, Triforce portrait frame, and The Echoes of the Mask wings. The ARPG formula of Diablo 3 was ideal for the pick-up-and-play style of gaming that the Switch offered, and Diablo 2: Resurrected coming to the console on day one showed that the platform was the Diablo series' perfect home. Unfortunately, Diablo 4 has not made its way to the Switch, likely due to the console's aging hardware, but the Switch 2's improved specs may be just what the game needs to finally release on a Nintendo console.

Diablo 4 Getting a Switch 2 Release Could Warrant a New amiibo

One of the best parts of Diablo 3 's Switch release was that a special Loot Goblin amiibo was released alongside it. While amiibo are most famously utilized by first-party Nintendo titles to add extra content to certain games, there have been a handful of third-party amiibo released in the past, including Diablo 3 's Loot Goblin. If Diablo 4 were to get a Switch 2 port, releasing an associated amiibo would be a great way to entice players to pick up the game on the new platform.

Diablo 4 could release on the Switch 2 as a bundle with the Vessel of Hatred expansion, much like how Diablo 3: Eternal Collection featured its expansions.

The hype for amiibo may have mostly died down, but the Switch 2 still has plans for the NFC-compatible figures, and several third-party amiibo have already been confirmed for the console. Aside from new amiibo for Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom , Street Fighter 6 is also receiving a series of amiibo figures and cards for its Switch 2 port, opening the door for more third-party developers to create figures for their own games. A Diablo 4 release on the Switch 2 in the interim between major expansions that brings a new amiibo figure with it would surely be cause for excitement among Nintendo and Diablo fans alike.

item.title: A Fake Schedule 1 Mobile Game Is Trending on Some App Stores
item.description:
Summary

  • A fake mobile version of Schedule 1 is topping the charts in some countries.
  • The game is priced at $4.99 USD and appears to be a port of the Schedule 1 demo, using assets from the original game.
  • Player reviews have labeled the game a "scam" and noted that it was not created by the original developer.

A fake mobile version of the smash hit Steam game, Schedule 1 , has made its way to the top of the charts in some countries. Schedule 1 entered early access on Steam last month, quickly finding success with hundreds of thousands of concurrent players. While the indie title receives regular upda tes, the sole developer of Schedule 1 has to confirm an official mobile port.

As of writing, Schedule 1 is only available on PC via Steam. While Tyler, the game's creator, has confirmed that official Steam Deck support is in the works, Schedule 1 is not available on consoles or mobile devices. Unfortunately, that doesn't appear to have prevented others from developing fake versions of the game. Earlier this month, Tyler warned fans that games appearing on the official PlayStation Store with "Schedule 1" in the name had no affiliation with him. Although he did state that he would "love to port Schedule 1 to console," the game is currently only available on PC.

Fake Schedule 1 Mobile Port Trends on App Store

While Tyler has yet to officially address the issue, fans have noticed that a fake mobile port of Schedule 1 has skyrocketed to the top of the charts in some countries. In the US, " Schedule 1 Drug Dealer ," priced at $4.99 USD, has reached the number one spot in the Entertainment category of the Apple App Store. The title features the same key art, name, and logo, and is supposedly an actual playable version of the game; however, it appears to have no affiliation with the game's developer, Tyler, also known as TVGS.

According to one user, the mobile game is actually a port of the title's demo, rather than the full game, meaning players will be unable to progress past a certain point in Schedule 1 's main story. While there appear to be a handful of positive reviews, some have called it a "scam" and noted that it was not created by the original developer. "If you pay, you will not get access to the full game," one review reads.

This appears to be the latest issue facing developer TVGS , following the huge success of Schedule 1 . Shortly after the game's early access release, Movie Games S.A., the publisher behind Drug Dealer Simulator , began an investigation into Schedule 1 as the studio believed it may have violated its intellectual property. Movie Games S.A. claims that Schedule 1 has used elements from Drug Dealer Simulator , including plot, gameplay mechanics, and user interface.

Players have also been having numerous issues with Schedule 1 mods, as many of the most popular ones appear to be infested with malware. Mods for any game should always be downloaded at the player's own risk ; however, there seems to be extra risk associated with Schedule 1 mods, as various mods, such as Just Enough Drugs and Better Casino, among others, have been found to be infested with malware.

item.title: Best Hunting Horn Weapons In Monster Hunter Wilds, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Glass Royale Hunting Horn focuses on stunning monsters with paralysis damage and echo bubbles for evasion.
  • Perun Clairhorn offers a mix of support and damage with thunder elements and helpful melodies for players.
  • Gramklang provides high affinity for critical hits, damage buffs, and earplugs for uninterrupted attacks.

Monster Hunter Wilds , like previous Monster Hunter titles, has players choosing from a wide assortment of weaponry. While many of the weapons in Monster Hunter Wilds have players wielding deadly blades such as the Long Sword or a Gunlance. However, since Monster Hunter Wilds can be enjoyed with others, there are weapons that work perfectly as a support role while also having the means to allow a player to fend for themselves while using them.

The Hunting Horn is quite different from the other weapons available in Monster Hunter , though it is also incredibly enjoyable to use. With plenty of Hunting Horns to craft, these are by far the best Hunter Horns in Monster Hunter Wilds , ranked.

8 Glass Royale

Stun Monsters In Place Constantly

  • Damage: 840
  • Status/Element: Paralysis
  • Skills: Protective Polish lv.3, Speed Sharpening lv. 2
  • Echo Bubble: Evasion & Movement Speed Up

Starting off strong, a great Hunting Horn option for players to consider is the Glass Royale Hunting Horn. While many of the weapon options in Monster Hunter Wilds , when focusing on the horns, usually look at the buffs it can give the player or the amount of damage it does, the Vespoid option in Monster Hunter Wilds is great for those who wish to exploit elemental damage, such as Paralysis.

The Glass Royale can stun a monster in place with this paralysis, as well as also be able to stun a monster with just the regular hits of the hunting horn. With echo bubbles that increase the movement of the player, it can also be a great option for those who struggle to get out of the way of the danger.

7 Perun Clairhorn

A Good Mix Between Support And Damage

  • Damage: 924
  • Status/Element: Thunder
  • Skills: Stamina Thief lv.3, Horn Maestro lv. 2
  • Echo Bubble: Health Regeneration

When using the Hunting Horn in Monster Hunter Wilds , the majority of this type of weapon tend to supply players with ways to support their team. However, some options like the Perun Clairhorn, which is made from the parts of Ray Dau, are perfect for those looking for a weapon that has a mix of melodies and decent damage to allow players to both support themselves and other hunters while also being able to fight confidently against monsters.

A player may use a small attack up melody to increase their damage, or put down a health regeneration echo bubble to bring up their health without needing to use any potions. This isn't even acknowledging the thunder damage that the horn also does.

6 Gramklang

Increase Affinity Through Song

  • Damage: 840
  • Status/Element: Dragon
  • Skills: Critical Element lv.3
  • Echo Bubble: Evasion & Movement Speed Up

Gramklang already has one of the highest affinity scores out of all the Hunting Horns in Monster Hunter Wilds . However, this high-damaging weapon can go even higher due to having melodies like Affinity/Healthy Recovery due to it increasing an already 20% affinity even higher to allow the player more chances at critically hitting a monster and then doing a bonus amount of damage to it.

With Earplugs also being available on this Hunting Horn, a player can therefore deal damage to a monster without the worry of being stunned by its screams, so that the damage can never stop against it.

5 War Conga

Plenty Of Supportive Melodies For Teams

  • Damage: 882
  • Status/Element: Raw
  • Skills: Horn Maestro lv. 2, Speed Sharpening lv. 1
  • Echo Bubble: Attack & Affinity Up

Players may be surprised to see the War Conga so high up on the list of the best Hunting Horns in Monster Hunter Wilds. Though it may have low affinity and less damage than most, this is the perfect weapon choice for any player who is hoping to enjoy hunting monsters with others.

With an assortment of melodies that can either increase the health recovery of a fellow player or even grant them an antidote if they have been poisoned, this Hunting Horn was made for a player who wishes to stay in the back and use various team synergies with other weapons to easily deal with monsters. While this weapon may not be useful when playing with random players, it still has plenty of potential when enjoying Monster Hunter Wilds with friends.

4 Summoning Bell

High Affinity And Ear Plugs On A Healing Horn

  • Damage: 882
  • Status/Element: Water
  • Skills: Slicked Blade lv. 3, Critical Element lv. 1
  • Echo Bubble: Stamina Regeneration

Although Monster Hunter Wilds already had plenty of monsters to fight and weapons to craft from them, the first large update for the game by Capcom added an old favorite for players to challenge themselves against once more. By fighting Mizutsune, players will obtain the materials needed to craft the powerful Summoning Bell, which has a lot of potential for those willing to create a build around it.

Besides being a healing horn, which means players can easily support themselves with it, the Summoning Bell is another Hunting Horn with which players can increase affinity. This, therefore, means they are more likely to critical hit opponents while dealing a large amount of damage.

3 Rathalos Feroce

High Damage And Ways To Buff It

  • Damage: 840
  • Status/Element: Fire
  • Skills: Critical Boost lv. 3
  • Echo Bubble: Evasion & Movement Speed Up

Opposing Water, another Hunting Horn option players should be sure to consider, is the ever-loved Rathalos Feroce. Since this monster has appeared in so many Monster Hunter games in the past, it's no surprise that the weapons made from it are also some of the best in the franchise, too. This includes Monster Hunter Wilds .

As a high-damage option, players may be surprised to see that its base damage may not be one of the best among other Hunting Horns. However, its melodies are perfect for players hoping to not only increase their defense, but also their attack, as well as burn away the health of monsters.

2 Resounding Galahad

Made For Maximum Damage

  • Damage: 882
  • Status/Element: Dragon
  • Skills: Slugger lv. 2, Horn Maestro lv 2
  • Echo Bubble: Defense & Elemental Res Up

When reaching the end game in Monster Hunter Wilds , it's important even for those using the Hunting Horn to make sure they are doing a large amount of damage so they can easily hold their own against some of the most extreme monsters in the game, especially when they are frenzied or tempered.

Although the player will have to fight Arkveld for the chance to make the Resounding Galahad, the Dragon elemental damage will also be perfect when fighting other difficult monsters. This is only made stronger by Attack Up (L).

1 Omiltika

A Fully Customizable Hunting Horn

  • Damage: 798
  • Status/Element: Any
  • Skills: N/A
  • Echo Bubble: Ailments/Blight Negated

By far, the best Hunting Horn players should consider making in Monster Hunter Wilds is the heavily customizable Artian Hunting Horn known as Omiltika. Players are able to fully create this Hunting Horn to fit their playstyle through collecting various parts that can then be put together to make a stronger weapon.

Therefore, a player may choose what elemental damage they wish to use, depending on the parts they select, as well as this also determining which melodies are available to players. Overall, when reaching the endgame, players should be sure to hone their Hunting Horn with this Artian option.

item.title: The Argument Against a Last of Us Part 3 Featuring Stun/Smoke Bombs
item.description:
The Last of Us has had inventive and improvisational kits for its playable characters. For example, thanks to Bill and his booby-trapped town in Lincoln, Massachusetts, players are introduced to nail bombs. Meanwhile, players are taught to be mindful of their environments and not trigger tripwires with bricks and bottles strewn about everywhere that they can throw to detonate and clear them. This is hardly the ideal use of a brick or bottle, though. Joels revolver and Ellies bow are iconic weapons in The Last of Us , but it is debatable that bricks and bottles are far greater staples of the series.

Molotovs are rarely wasteful as long as players can shepherd a pack of infected, but there will always come a time when players lack the required resource ingredients in order to craft one. Likewise, unarmed fist-fighting as Joel or Abby in their respective games is also not easily advised due to how quickly players can become overwhelmed. Of course, no scenario is truly doomed if players have a brick or bottle at the ready. Oddly enough, Part 2 debuted stun bombs (upgraded with supplements to become a variant of Part 1 s smoke bombs), which only further exemplify how inspired bricks and bottles are in The Last of Us .

The Last of Us Part 1s Bricks are a Clickers Worst Nightmare

In The Last of Us Part 1 , bricks are a ubiquitous yet indispensable resource, especially on harder difficulties, because a three-hit combo with one can kill a clicker. Thus, unlike the bottle, bricks are powerful melee weapons as well as throwables used to create distractions or temporarily stagger enemies. Bricks are terrific, too, if players wish to preserve as many shivs as possible so that they can access every shiv door in the game, which in turn allows players to preserve the durability of reinforced melee weapons.

This strategy is moot once Ellie becomes playable in The Last of Us wintertime and during her Left Behind DLC since she can kill clickers swiftly from stealth with her switchblade.

Part 1 features smoke bombs that are easily forgotten about unless players are throwing the kitchen sink at enemies. And, having been the precursor to stun/smoke bombs, in Part 2 , its ironic that players truly dont need to prioritize smoke bombs in their crafting inventory so long as they have spare bricks or bottles around.

The Last of Us Part 2 Juggles Stun Items Redundantly

Sadly, bricks are nerfed in The Last of Us Part 2 as theyre no more effective than a bottle, becoming mere reskins of one another. This is proven by the fact that bricks cannot be swapped for bottles and vice versa like they can in Part 1 , meaning there is no longer a distinction between them, and the likely culprit as to why may be to emphasize stun/smoke bombs instead.

Contrary to their lack of memorability in The Last of Us story campaigns, stun bombs are incredibly effective and downright vital in Part 2 s roguelike mode, No Return, as bricks and bottles are scarce in any given encounter and craftable stun bombs can be a godsend when cornered in Assault, Holdout, or Hunted, much less boss encounters such as the Seraphite Elite.

Rather, Abbys arsenal replaces stun/smoke bombs with explosive pipe bombs to complement her offensive capabilities. On the whole, Abbys playstyle is the closer of the two to how Joel plays in Part 1 , complete with craftable shivs that Abby can now use to break free from any grapple if players dont want to mash square and lose more health in the scramble. So, it mightve made sense for bricks to at least be as powerful as they were in Part 1 , at least while Abby is wielding them.

Instead, stun bombs and smoke bombs join a wide catalog of craftable items, with the latter item creating a smokescreen. It may have ironically made more sense for Abby to have wielded stun/smoke bombs since her association with the WLF militia wouldve been a better excuse as to why shes armed to the teeth and may not resort to bricks and bottles as much as Ellie may have while out on patrol. Either way, a Last of Us Part 3 should honor and respect bricks and bottles by not feeling obligated to nudge other stun tools into players inventories.
